sec_txt.h3: The Changing Landscape of RA Management: Focus on the JAK Inhibitors
Faculty
Introduction/Overview
Cytokines, Growth Factors, and Signaling Pathways Involved in RA Pathogenesis[1-3]

ul.li: Many cytokines and growth factors converge upon the Janus kinase signal transducer and activator of transcription (JAK-STAT) pathway in the furtherance of extracellular/intracellular communication
In the rheumatoid synovial membrane, for example, Janus kinase (JAK) recruitment subsequently provokes STAT phosphorylation, which then facilitates nucleus translocation and gene expression

sec_txt.h3: The Biological Significance of Signaling Through Different JAK Combinations[4-7]

ul.li: Different combinations of cytokine ligands, JAKs, and STATs confer the possibility of different combinations of signals arriving at the cell nucleus, and thus of a wide range of information exchanges between the extracellular environment and the cell
This in turn leads to a wide possibility of cell behaviors
Contrast this with the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) pathway or interleukin (IL)-6 pathway, which is more discrete
Therapeutically, this is not a problem, as it suggests the possibility of combinatorial approaches to block complementary pro-inflammatory pathways

sec_txt.h3: IL-6 in Inflammation, Immunity, and Disease[8-12]

ul.li: The role of IL-6 in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) pathogenesis may perhaps best be illustrated in the acute-phase response, with IL-6 implicated in elevated levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) and increases in the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
Both CRP and ESR commonly accompany inflammatory disease in general and RA in particular
IL-6 has also been implicated in joint destruction and in the systemic manifestations observed in RA, for example, anemia

sec_txt.h3: Tumor Necrosis Factor and the Pathogenesis of RA[13]

ul.li: The role of TNF in autoimmune disorders was first elucidated some decades ago

TNF plays a key role in the network of cellular and protein responses associated with inflammatory processes. Pathobiologically, these inflammatory responses are associated, in autoimmune joint diseases, with cartilage degradation, bone erosion, and joint destruction

sec_txt.h3: Selective JAK Inhibition: Advantages?[14]

ul.li: The question as to whether or not selective inhibition of JAK, as opposed to more broad-brush inhibition of multiple kinases, would have advantages; such as, possibly, a cleaner safety profile
Current research is striving to answer those questions

sec_txt.h3: JAK Inhibitors in RA[15-18]
Tofacitinib and Baricitinib: Key Questions for JAK

ul.li: Optimizing dosing in various patient scenarios is the key question for JAK inhibitors

sec_txt.h3: Tofacitinib JAK 1/3 Inhibitor: Clinical Trials in RA[16,17,19,20]

ul.li: Tofacitinib is a small-molecule JAK 1/3 inhibitor that has been approved by both the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for the treatment of RA
Tofacitinib's efficacy and safety have been assessed in a comprehensive clinical development program

sec_txt.h3: Baricitinib: Key Studies in RA Phase 3 Program and Their Characteristics[21-24]

ul.li: Baricitinib is a small-molecule JAK 1/2 inhibitor that has been approved by both the FDA and EMA for the treatment of RA
Baricitinib's efficacy and safety have been assessed in a comprehensive clinical development program

sec_txt.h3: EULAR Recommendations for RA Management[25]

ul.li: Methotrexate remains the first-line treatment for RA
Rheumatologists appreciate its good efficacy and safety record, as well as its huge titratable range, which means doses can be adjusted to patient specifics

sec_txt.h3: Tofacitinib or ADA vs PBO in RA: Results From ORAL Standard[16]

ul.li: In ORAL Standard, a 12-month, phase 3 trial, 717 patients who were receiving stable doses of methotrexate were randomly assigned to 5 mg of tofacitinib twice daily, 10 mg of tofacitinib twice daily, 40 mg of adalimumab once every 2 weeks, or placebo

Primary outcome measures were a 20% improvement at month 6 in the American College of Rheumatology 20 score (ACR20), the change from baseline to month 3 in health assessment questionnaire-disability index (HAQ-DI) score, and the percentage of patients at month 6 who had a disease activity score (DAS) of 28 or ESR of less than 2.6
For the ACR20 score, both doses of tofacitinib were superior to adalimumab

sec_txt.h3: RA-BUILD: Efficacy of Baricitinib in RA Patients With an Inadequate Response to csDMARDs[22]

ul.li: For many clinicians, the question becomes what to do for those patients who seem to have an inadequate response to first-line methotrexate: 1) replace methotrexate with another agent used as monotherapy, or 2) add a biologic to methotrexate?

RA-BUILD was a phase 3, double-blind, 24-week study, wherein 684 biologics-naive patients with RA and an inadequate response to or intolerance of ≥ 1 conventional synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (csDMARDs) were randomly assigned 1:1:1 to placebo or baricitinib (2 or 4 mg) once daily
Primary endpoints were changes in ACR20, DAS28, and Simplified Disease Activity Index (SDAI)
At week 12, the ACR20 response was 62% for baricitinib 4 mg, and 59% for baricitinib 2 mg vs 39% for placebo (P <.001); all study agents (including placebo) were added to stable background therapy
The evidence seems to be that the add-on strategy is superior to switching between monotherapies

sec_txt.h3: Baricitinib Monotherapy vs Methotrexate and Baricitinib + Methotrexate: RA-BEGIN[23]

ul.li: But not all the evidence
In RA-BEGIN, for example, 588 patients were randomized 4:3:4 to receive methotrexate monotherapy (once weekly), baricitinib monotherapy (4 mg once daily), or the combination for 52 weeks

For many of the study endpoints, including HAQ-DI, the treatment effects observed for baricitinib monotherapy and the combination of baricitinib and methotrexate were statistically similar, and both were superior to methotrexate monotherapy

sec_txt.h3: RA-BEAM Phase 3: ACR Outcomes at Weeks 12 and 24[24]

ul.li: RA-BEAM was a phase 3, 52-week, double-blind, placebo- and active-controlled trial in which 1307 patients with active RA on background methotrexate were randomly assigned to 1 of 3 regimens in a 3:3:2 ratio: placebo (switched to baricitinib after 24 weeks), 4 mg of baricitinib once daily, or 40 mg of adalimumab every other week
Baricitinib demonstrated statistically significant superiority vs adalimumab in ACR20, ACR50, and ACR70 responses at week 12
This study was the first to show that a targeted therapy — in this case, an oral, once daily, small molecule — was actually better than the standard of care, methotrexate plus adalimumab

sec_txt.h3: Adalimumab for RA: Results From the PREMIER Trial[26]

ul.li: PREMIER was a double-blind, active comparator–controlled study of 799 (methotrexate-naive) RA patients with active disease of < 3 years’ duration
Treatments included adalimumab 40 mg subcutaneously every other week plus methotrexate, adalimumab 40 mg subcutaneously every other week, or weekly oral methotrexate
Significantly more patients (62%, P <.001) on the combination of adalimumab and methotrexate achieved an ACR50 response vs patients on adalimumab alone or methotrexate alone

sec_txt.h3: ACR50 Responses Tofacitinib Monotherapy vs Tofacitinib + MTX and Adalimumab + MTX: ORAL Strategy[27]

ul.li:
In this trial, monotherapy tofacitinib was not found to be noninferior to the combination of adalimumab or tofacitinib with methotrexate, but it was also not found to be inferior to those combinations in terms of primary endpoint results (ie, ACR50 response at month 6)
“Not noninferior” is a difficult concept. What is clear is that tofacitinib monotherapy does very well in some patients, but the combination of either tofacitinib or adalimumab with methotrexate does better

sec_txt.h3: PROs: RA-BEAM Phase 3 Trial of Baricitinib[28]

ul.li: A number of patient-reported outcomes (PROs) are now being routinely assessed in many clinical trials. And these assessments make use of a variety of measurement tools and indices

sec_txt.h3: Patient Assessment of Joint Pain Reduction[29]

ul.li: The study by Louder and colleagues assessed patient preferences regarding RA agent attributes
Joint pain reduction is one of the most important patient-reported preferences

sec_txt.h3: RA-BEAM: Joint Pain Reduction[30]

ul.li: In RA-BEAM, joint pain reduction was one of the secondary endpoints measured
Pain reduction occurred more rapidly and with greater magnitude in the baricitinib plus methotrexate arm

sec_txt.h3: RA-BEACON: Baricitinib in RA Patients With an Inadequate Response to TNFα Inhibitors[21]

ul.li: RA-BEACON involved 527 patients with an inadequate response or unacceptable side effects with 1 or more TNF inhibitors, other biologics, or both
Patients were randomized to placebo, baricitinib 2 mg, or baricitinib 4 mg once daily for 24 weeks
In these difficult-to-manage patients, 55% of the baricitinib 4 mg arm achieved an ACR20 response at week 12 vs 27% of placebo patients (P <.001)

sec_txt.h3: JAK Inhibitors: Safety Considerations[16,17,19-22,24,31,32]

ul.li: Infections have been noted with JAK inhibitors, but to no greater extent than that noted for other biologics inhibiting the immune response
An elevation in herpes zoster risk has been observed, but, clinically, a substantial enhancement of zoster reactivation has not been reported

sec_txt.h3: RA Is Associated with an Approximately 2-Fold Increase in VTE Over Healthy Controls[33,34]

ul.li: RA is itself a risk factor for thromboembolism
Patients with RA have approximately double the risk for venous thromboembolism (VTE) and/or pulmonary embolism (PE) as to matched cohorts without RA

sec_txt.h3: Baricitinib and VTE: The FDA Arthritis Advisory Committee April 23, 2018, Meeting[35]

ul.li: Recently some concerns have been raised regarding JAK inhibitors and thromboembolic risk
At an April 2018 meeting of the FDA Arthritis Advisory Committee, baricitinib with regard to VTE was discussed

Data presented on baricitinib indicated an imbalance of VTE in the placebo-controlled period, but that patients had 1 or more VTE risk factors (eg, older age, higher body mass index [BMI], COX-2 inhibitor use compared with matched controls without RA)
An increased VTE risk not found in patients switched to baricitinib, and there was an absence of a temporal relationship between baricitinib use and VTE

sec_txt.h3: Odds Ratio and Empirical Bayesian Geometric Mean Values for Thromboembolic Adverse Events[36]

ul.li: Verden and colleagues assessed postmarket case reports of thromboembolic events possibly associated with JAK inhibitors
Elevated reporting rates for VTE and PE specifically associated with JAK inhibitors were not found

However, the FDA’s Adverse Event Reporting System (FAERS) data indicated a potential class-wide issue for JAK inhibitors and pulmonary thrombosis
This issue needs to be confirmed by subsequent reporting data and/or clinical trials

sec_txt.h3: Summary and Conclusions
Thank You
sec_txt.em: This content has been condensed for improved clarity.
